trans-unit.source: Represents a Windows menu control that enables you to hierarchically organize elements associated with commands and event handlers.
The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu> control presents a list of items that specify commands or options for an application.
Typically, clicking an item on a menu opens a submenu or causes an application to carry out a command.
<xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu> is an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>, which means it can contain a collection of objects of any type (such as string, image, or panel).
For more information, see the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl> class.
The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.MenuItem> is the most common type of item in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu>.
A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.MenuItem> can contain child items.
The child items will appear in a submenu when the user chooses a parent <xref:System.Windows.Controls.MenuItem>.
Customizing the Menu Control
To apply the same property settings to multiple <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu> controls, use the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Style%2A> property.
You can modify the default <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> to give the control a unique appearance.

For more information about creating a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate>, see [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/customizing-the-appearance-of-an-existing-control.md).
To see the parts and states that are specific to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu>, see [Menu Styles and Templates](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/menu-styles-and-templates.md).
Dependency properties for this control might be set by the controlâ€™s default style.
If a property is set by a default style, the property might change from its default value when the control appears in the application.
The default style is determined by which desktop theme is used when the application is running.
For more information, see [Default WPF Themes](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=158252).
Setting a visual property will only have an effect if that property is both present in <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu> control's default template and is set by using a .

You can find a list of visual properties in the "Changing the Visual Structure of a Control" section in [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/customizing-the-appearance-of-an-existing-control.md).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.Menu"></xref> class.
Called when any mouse button is pressed or released.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether this <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.Menu"></xref> receives a main menu activation notification.

If there are multiple <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu> controls on a page, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu> controls that should not receive ALT or F10 key notifications should set this property to `false`.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None
`true` if the menu receives a main menu activation notification; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.Menu.IsMainMenu"></xref> dependency property.

Provides an appropriate <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.Peers.MenuAutomationPeer"></xref> implementation for this control, as part of the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] automation infrastructure.
The type-specific <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.Peers.AutomationPeer"></xref> implementation.
Called when the <xref href="System.Windows.FrameworkElement.IsInitialized"></xref> property is set to `true`.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Responds to the <xref href="System.Windows.ContentElement.KeyDown"></xref> event.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Handles the <xref href="System.Windows.UIElement.TextInput"></xref> routed event that occurs when the menu receives text input from any device.
This implementation does not change the handled state (the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property) of the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.TextInput> event data.
The event data.
Prepares the specified element to display the specified item.
Preparing the element might involve applying styles, setting bindings, and so on.
The element used to display the specified item.
The item to display.
